Stuart Wheeler: A conservative exiled to the heart of UKIP

25/07/2013

Rich, connected and a Tory Party expellee. Stuart Wheeler tells Tom Witherow why the Conservatives have let him down, the dangers of the Farage-factor and why you probably won't get a vote on Europe.

Image by

By undefined undefined

The left tangibly rejoiced at the latest poll from ICM which placed Labour and the Conservatives level-pegging on 36%. The latter's supposed recovery at the expense of UKIP (7%) whose support had peaked at 20%, after a shock victory of 150 council seats in the May's local elections. The ICM poll has also been accompanied by a silence from UKIP HQ, and especially from Nigel Farage, its enigmatic leader who for a few months was a constant presence on screens and in the written press. Many would believe (or perhaps just hope) that they've given up - resigned to May being a localised spike in support that was shot down as soon as their policies were placed under any sort of scrutiny. But then a poll is just a poll. The previous ten had them on 10, 20, 19, 13, 18, 13, 12, 13, 10 and 12. But even then, there could hardly be a less relevant time for a short-term drive, with the summer recess just around the corner. Perhaps the real test will come in the Autumn with conference season and the build-up to the European elections next year. And so it is probably wise that Farage and team have retreated to UKIP HQ to work on policy, strategy, and all-important fund-raising. Enter Stuart Wheeler. Banking millionaire who made his money as the City took off in the 70s and 80s pioneering spread betting. His company IG Index grew massively until it went public in 2000, making Wheeler a significant cash fortune. Since then he has brought his attention to politics, gaining national fame with the largest donation to a political party in history. PS5 million the sum, after he met William Hague at a dinner party and had "been impressed by him". All in an evening's work for Hague I'm sure.
"Let me not disguise the fact that I was expelled from the Conservative Party"
Wheeler is charming, an Old Etonian who'd rather not talk about it. At a party he threw at his country home (Chilham Castle) a few years ago he announced that he hated having to worry whether he could sleep his guests. Fortunately that will no longer be a problem. But behind the kind 78-year-old who tells me to speak up on account of his deafness is a formidable political force. "Let me not disguise the fact that I was expelled from the Conservative Party", he says bluntly when I ask why he switched allegiances. In previous interviews he has said that he would have stayed - perhaps it is a foolish man that considers a man as wealthy and well connected as Stuart Wheeler, with a lifetime of contacts in high society and the City, expendable. "I think we are in some senses conservative with a small c, as opposed to Conservative as it is at the moment, who have deserted conservatism." This indictment of modern Conservatism is precisely what UKIP thrives on. When he clarifies that "a lot of our voters think that we're left wing rather than right wing. And we do very well in Labour constituencies." The great strength of UKIP is that they supersede party boundaries. They hark back to a British identity, which the left would argue is a figment of reactionary imagination. With UKIP's policies there is no boundary between rich and poor, or left and right, only 'sensible' or 'common sense' policies, or as Wheeler puts it, "I think it's through being sensible, and having sensible policies." Sensible policies? Sensible policies such as preventing anyone immigrating unless we need their skills (forget Britons' regional immobility or productivity discrepancies in certain sectors), returning to pre-Blair levels of public spending (at a cost of 2 million public sector jobs) and scrapping the Human Rights Act. Wheeler doesn't agree with the latter - "I took on my job of treasurer on the understanding that I could disagree with our policy on human rights" - but does with the rest. "We are too full. We are a small country in area and very densely populated so for the next five years we would not allow people to come who simply want to live here." For so many around the country who can't see the benefits of immigration, only the communalism that an overtly multi-culturalist policy has brought about in some areas of Britain, this kind of rhetoric without facts, figures and economic theory is undoubtedly appealing. Wheeler himself is unwilling to go into too much detail telling me on separate occasions that he's not an economist, he's not in charge of policy, and the party hasn't finalized its policy on that. But no matter how poorly defined, public spending cuts are attractive. But UKIP shows itself to be a party of protest when it comes to the numbers. "I don't think we have a particular time period, but the sooner the better really." The sooner the better? The UKIP manifesto announces boldly that lower taxes will bring foreign investment flooding in to the tune of 1 million jobs, and that manufacturing subsidies will take care of the other million. But this clearly won't happen overnight - the fallout would be a curse on confidence and the country's unstable recovery. His problem with human rights comes down to interpretation, and there are no prizes for guessing where the heart of the problem is. "The act itself is fine. It's just the court that deals with it is not fine. Each of the 46 or 47 member states involved produces one judge, and one of those states has about 40,000 people and one has 80 million. So there's a very big discrepancy between various judge's ability and so forth." Europe is at the heart of Wheeler's UKIP, even if that isn't the case for their voters - "although we think that the most important policy is getting out of the EU, voters who support us put that fourth". At times I feel he has to remember that UKIP is no longer a one-policy party, but then Wheeler's political career has come to be defined by Europe. "The reason for my expulsion [from the Conservative Party] was that I was fed up with the Conservative's inability, as I saw it, to deal with the European Union question, that is to get us out of it. So I said I would vote UKIP in the 2009 European Elections and would give them some money, both of which I did." He accuses Cameron of vote-swindling, playing the electorate for all its worth on an emotive issue that divides parties and voting demographics alike. His approach, according to Wheeler, is "thoroughly unsatisfactory. It's absolutely clear that Cameron, if he does get in again and we have the referendum as promised, after the negotiations, no matter what we get, he'll come back and say 'what a triumph, let's vote to stay in'." And as Wheeler is keen to point out, Cameron's promise need only be kept in the case of a Conservative majority. "The bookmakers at least until recently were laying 4-1 on the Conservative winning an overall majority, so if it depended on that the odds are we won't have a referendum." And this coming from a man who when I spoke to him had just returned from a week at the table in Vegas... He believes adamantly that this promise, however unlikely it is to come through would not have come about without the pressure placed on Tories by UKIP. And he doesn't think it will stop there. "I think it likely that the Labour Party, and possibly the Liberal Democrats perhaps as well, will change their minds before the election and will have an in or out referendum. I think they'll see that it'll cost them too many votes if they don't". This kind of observation points to UKIP remaining a permanent fixture in British politics. Europe will remain on out doorstep, and while the architects seek closer political and economic union across a larger area there will be backlash in isolationist Britain. What is certain is that Farage will be key, but Wheeler is concerned that the party is at risk of being seen as a 'one-man band': "Partly it's a virtuous or vicious circle, because he's so good it's difficult when he's who the media wants, for someone else to get the reputation they deserve. Actually we have a lot of good people." But he is forced to admit that it is his "fantastic energy" and media persona that has led to UKIP's success, "more than anything else". For now Wheeler has placed his chips on a shade of purple, while his role moves to gathering the dues of his high society associates in a bid to give UKIP a shot in the two most important elections of its (relatively) short lifespan. And even in the likely event they don't enter parliament, they will still exert pressure and influence over those that do. "I think we've hit something the public really likes. The public don't trust politicians from other parties." The class of 2010 has already shown itself to be fresh compared to careerists such as Clegg, Cameron and Miliband - one can only hope that the same is true of 2015's intake. For now Stuart Wheeler has no intentions to retire, making the most of a late entry into politics. "I was already an old man by the time I got involved. It was rather odd really." Considering he thought it "unfair" that Labour was getting more in donations than the Tories in the early noughties, he seems a whimsical man, but one shouldn't be fooled. Even if his daughter did greet his job at UKIP with a 'whatever makes you happy, Daddy.'
